Approval Process: All demonstrations must have an Illinois Tech-affiliated sponsor,
whether one or more currently enrolled student in good standing or an authorized officer of
a university-recognized student organization (“Sponsor”). The Sponsor must submit a fully
completed application no less than ten (10) calendar days in advance of the proposed
Demonstration date in a form approved by the Office of the Dean of Students. The Dean of
Students, or designee, in consultation with other Illinois Tech officials as they deem
necessary, shall consider the time, place, and manner of the proposed demonstration and,
in their collective discretion, may approve, conditionally approve, or deny the request. If an
application is conditionally approved, the Office of the Dean of Students and applicant
shall work together in an attempt to resolve outstanding concerns before the application
can be fully approved. The Demonstration must be conducted consistent with all special
conditions reflected in the approval, the guidelines set forth herein, all applicable Illinois
Tech policies including, without limitation, the Student Code of Conduct, as well as
applicable federal, state and municipal laws. The Sponsor is responsible for taking all
necessary steps to ensure compliance with these requirements by all participants, and
may be held accountable for violations by any person involved in the Demonstration.
Conduct of Demonstration. Illinois Tech reserves the right to regulate the time, place and
manner of a proposed Demonstration, and to withhold approval if it reasonably appears
that the Demonstration is to be organized by or on behalf of individuals or organizations
that are not affiliated with Illinois Tech, or which are intended or deemed likely to disrupt or
interfere with Illinois Tech operations or the mission of the university. By way of example
only, Demonstrations, even those that have received prior approval, involving any of the
following activities will not be permitted:
 Prevent, delay, impede or disrupt university functions or activities, such as classes,
lectures, meetings, ceremonies, performances, or other similar events, or the
conduct of university business.
 Obstruct the legitimate movement of any person or vehicle on Illinois Tech
premises;
 Be within 200 feet of another Demonstration;
 Be near places where minors or other vulnerable populations are present including,
without limitation, the Student Health and Wellness Center;
 Be violent or harassing, or create, or have the potential to create, a hostile or
threatening environment, or threaten individual or public health and safety;

 Deface or damage, or pose a reasonable possibility to damage, Illinois Tech
property or personal property, including but not limited to buildings and their
contents, utilities, security systems, vehicles, signage, artwork and landscaping;
 Involve burning objects or combustible substances;
 Involve the construction or placement of structures, however temporary, including
encampments;
 Use sound amplification equipment;
 Result in unauthorized access to an Illinois Tech facility, or obstruction of the
entrance or exit to a university facility or roadway; or
 Failure to follow the reasonable instructions of an Illinois Tech representative
including, without limitation, an order to vacate university property or a university
facility.
The Sponsor is responsible for all associated costs of the Demonstrations (including
security if deemed necessary by Illinois Tech in its sole discretion), as well as securing any
permits required by applicable law. Organizing or participating in a Demonstration without
prior authorization may result in disciplinary action.
V. ACADEMIC AND DEPARTMENT REGULATIONS
Rules and regulations are a necessary part of life, even in an academic environment, for
they define boundaries of conduct that allow an individual the maximum degree of
freedom consistent with the effective functioning of that community. The following
regulations, derived from applicable laws and regulatory requirements and the experience
of operating and maintaining an institution of higher education, summarize some of the
academic-related boundaries at Illinois Tech. It is important that all students familiarize
themselves with this material. In addition, undergraduate students should become
familiar with the regulations and procedures listed in the current Undergraduate Bulletin
and other publications from the Office of Undergraduate Academic Affairs; graduate
students should become familiar with the regulations and procedures listed in the current
Graduate Bulletin and other publications from the Office of Graduate Academic Affairs.
Law students should become familiar with the regulations and procedures listed in the
current Chicago-Kent Bulletin and Chicago-Kent Student Handbook. It is the responsibility
of all students to know and to adhere to relevant academic regulations and procedures
outlined in these publications. In the event of any conflict between the provisions of Article
